item.title: Tuning a stacked learner
item.dc:creator: Milan Dragicevic
Giuseppe Casalicchio
item.description: This tutorial explains how create and tune a multilevel stacking model using the mlr3pipelines package.

item.title: Pipelines, selectors, branches
item.dc:creator: Milan Dragicevic
Giuseppe Casalicchio
item.description: This tutorial explains how applying different preprocessing steps on different features and branching of preprocessing steps can be achieved using the mlr3pipelines package.

item.title: Imbalanced data handling with mlr3
item.dc:creator: Giuseppe Casalicchio
item.description: This use case compares different approaches to handle class imbalance for the optdigits (https://www.openml.org/d/980) binary classification data set using the mlr3 package.

item.title: Resampling: stratified, blocked and predefined
item.dc:creator: Milan Dragicevic
Giuseppe Casalicchio
item.description: When evaluating machine learning algorithms through resampling, it is preferable that each train/test partition will be a representative subset of the whole data set. This post covers three ways to achieve such reliable resampling procedures.

item.title: mlr3 basics on "iris" - Hello World!
item.dc:creator: Bernd Bischl
item.description: This use case shows how to use the basic mlr3 package on the iris task, so it's our "Hello World" example. It assumes no prior knowledge in machine learning or mlr3.

item.title: A pipeline for the titanic data set
item.dc:creator: Florian Pfisterer
item.description: This post shows how to build a Graph using the mlr3pipelines package on the "titanic" dataset.

item.title: mlr3pipelines tutorial - german credit
item.dc:creator: Martin Binder
Florian Pfisterer
item.description: In this tutorial we will continue working with the German Credit Dataset. We already used different Learners on it in previous posts and tried to optimize their hyperparameters. To make things interesting, we introduce missing values into the dataset.

item.title: mlr3tuning tutorial - german credit
item.dc:creator: Martin Binder
Florian Pfisterer
item.description: We evaluate all algorithms using 10-fold cross-validation. We use a fixed train-test split, i.e. the same splits for each evaluation. Otherwise, some evaluation could get unusually "hard" splits, which would make comparisons unfair.

item.title: mlr3 basics - german credit
item.dc:creator: Martin Binder
Florian Pfisterer
item.description: mlr3 is a machine learning framework for R. Together with other packages from the same developers, mostly following the naming scheme "mlr3___", it offers functionality around developing, tuning, and evaluating machine learning workflows.

item.title: Select uncorrelated features
item.dc:creator: Martin Binder
Florian Pfisterer
item.description: The following example describes a situation where we aim to remove correlated features. This in essence means, that we drop features until no features have a correlation higher then a given `cutoff`. This is often useful when we for example want to use linear models.

item.title: Tuning Over Multiple Learners
item.dc:creator: Jakob Richter
Bernd Bischl
item.description: This use case shows how to tune over multiple learners for a single task.

item.title: Impute missing variables
item.dc:creator: Florian Pfisterer
item.description: We show how to use mlr3pipelines to augment the "mlr_learners_classif.ranger" learner with automatic imputation.

item.title: Encode factor levels for xgboost
item.dc:creator: Michel Lang
item.description: The package "xgboost" unfortunately does not support handling of categorical features. Therefore it is required to manually convert factor columns to numerical dummy features. We show how to use "mlr3pipelines" to augment the "mlr_learners_classif.xgboost" learner with an automatic factor encoding.

item.title: House prices in King County
item.dc:creator: Florian Pfisterer
item.description: Use case illustrating data preprocessing and model fitting via mlr3 on the "King County House Prices" dataset.
